newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK central bank injects HK$1.0 bln in money market.
newsitem.headline: HK central bank injects HK$1.0 bln in money market.

text.p: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), the territory's defacto central bank, said it injected HK$1.0 billion into the interbank market on Friday morning in view of the tight liquidity of the local cash market.
"The action is aimed to soothe the tightness in cash because there is strong fund demand in the interbank market," an HKMA executive said.
Interbank dealers said the overnight rate surged to a high of 6-1/4 percent before settled at 6 5-7/8 percent at midday.
"Borrowing was very active this morning as traders were preparing for the month-end demand and for a stock's initial public offer," one U.S. bank dealer said.
Heavy oversubscription was seen on China property and hotel investor Nam Fong International Holdings Ltd's 68 million shares public offer, which will close at noon on Friday.
This is the second HKMA intervention within a week following a HK$598 million net injection made on Monday.
